Negative indices

Sometimes a number is raised to a negative power. This is interpreted as follows:

Key Point

Negative Powers

\(a^{-m} = \dfrac{1}{a^m}, \qquad a^m = \dfrac{1}{a^{-m}}\)

Thus a negative index can be used to indicate a reciprocal.

Example

Write each of the following expressions using a positive index and simplify if possible.

  1. \(2^{-3}\)
  2. \(\dfrac{1}{4^{-3}}\)
  3. \(x^{-1}\)
  4. \(x^{-2}\)
  5. \(10^{-1}\)

Solution

  1. \(2^{-3} = \dfrac{1}{2^3} = \dfrac{1}{8}\)
  2. \(\dfrac{1}{4^{-3}} = 4^3 = 64\)
  3. \(x^{-1}= \dfrac{1}{x^1}=\dfrac{1}{x}\)
  4. \(x^{-2}= \dfrac{1}{x^2}\)
  5. \(10^{-1}=\dfrac{1}{10^1}= \dfrac{1}{10} \) or \( 0.1\)
